review: This new galaxy tab s2 is light, snappy, bright , and beautiful. It arrived with marshmallow already installed and loaded up all the apps from my galaxy s7 edge with a single click. So far, so good with this one.
This is the new refreshed version of the galaxy tab s2 with android marshmallow 6.1, with the new snapdragon processor. The tablet is great. Runs smoothly. I love it.

Update Feb 1, 2017 -- Samsung is scheduled to roll out Nougat for this model in the next couple of months. Unfortunately the Samsung update they released in the last week or so has severely impacted the wifi connection when it wakes up from sleep. I had updates turned off so I'm very annoyed. My tablet isn't quite bricked but having to wait five minutes for wifi to fully connect makes it nearly useless. I am dropping a star for this.

Original review, May 2016 -- Yes, this model SM-T713 indeed has Marshmallow, 6.0.1 out of the box. If the confusing listing was holding you back go ahead and purchase, but read on.

Gorgeous display. I have never seen better in an 8" format. Quick, responsive, everything you'd expect from a higher end Samsung. Battery life greatly improved with Marshmallow on this model compared to Lollipop. I'm not in love with the screen ratio, but I'm not big on watching anything but short videos on tablets so lack of "wide screen" format isn't that much of a minus for me. I'm giving it 3.5 stars rounded up to 4 because of the Super AMOLED display.

Major quibble though about the amount of bloat on here. I intentionally chose Samsung S2 because I mistakenly thought there would be less bloatware. Not true. It's just better quality bloat. I do not need the entire Microsoft Office Suite on an 8" tablet. In fact, I need none of it. Plus all the Office apps are available for free as stand-alone apps, so you can pick and chose. Why saddle us with an unmovable memory hog? (Never mind, I know the answer.) Flipboard takes up an entire screen. You can press and pinch which effectively disables it but that screen is no longer available for use. That plus all the junk Samsung sticks on there are taking up over a third of the memory. Little of it can be disabled. None can be moved to SD. I have installed seven apps and no data so far and it's using over 40% of available RAM after I clean. I have at least 20 more apps to go and I'm very concerned I'll max it out.

If I had known this I wouldn't have bought it. This is not just buyer's remorse. I'd return it if I could.

This review is for the newer model of Samsung S2 the SM-T813 model, which is the 2016 model. The older S2 was the 810 model that was released in 2015. I owned the original S2 and loaned it to a friend because his older tablet broke. And he loves it so much that I gifted it to him for his birthday. Then, I decided to purchase the newer 813 the 2016 model for myself. Since I am a TECHIE type, I tested it thoroughly. This review is based on my personal experience with this tablet. Hopefully, this review will help you in your decision to purchase (or not), this device.

PROS:

1) STORAGE: So I purchased this tablet from an Amazon seller and jt was described as like new still in the box. I was happily surprised when this tablet arrived with 64 GB internal storage, not the 32GB of Internal Storage that was advertised. However, I cannot promise that all of these will have 64GB. ...however after the OS and Factory Apps, it had 52gb left. After I installed lots of personal Apps, I have 50.71gb left. Plenty left if I want to install more apps or updates on apps.
* Note that the advertised Internal Storage space and available storage space is different because the advertised internal storage space is BEFORE the OS was factory installed, Factory Apps installed and Touch Wiz overlay. These take up about 11GB of the space. And the tablet updated with 385GB after I turned it on the first time.
It came with Nougat 7.0 preinstalled, then installed a large performance update. It is running very, very fast after the update and the battery life had improved some as well.

2) Android OS and updates...My tablet arrived with Nougat 7.0 pre-installed. And it auto updated a minor/improvement update of 385GB. After the update, it ran very fast, seemed faster.
Flagship Samsung tablets are supposed to get two OS Upgrades. I looked up on Google to see, some sites said yes Oreo for the 813 model, so did not know. I am hoping so because my old 810 model (2015), received 2 OS updates.

3) WiFi---My WiFi Router connected immediately to this phone and it is a fast WiFi. The WiFi is super strong and I receive 5 bars around my home and it keeps the connection even in my backyard.

4) Display---The display is very, very clear and colors vivid as it has very high sharpness. Reading on Internet or PDF Book, the text is crisp. The videos in YouTube are very clear as well.

5) Speed and Performance---For my personal use, I find the speed and performance excellent for the things I do such as Facebook, Twitter, Internet, YouTube, Email, etc. I do not play games on this tablet yet I found all videos run very well.
Performs well, no lagging and no freezing.

6) WiFi calling---Yes, I can make phone calls on this WIFI ONLY device using my Google Voice account and Hangouts. Note that this model is NOT a cellular device, to make a phone call, WiFi must be on and a WiFi calling app such as Hangouts or other WiFi calling apps are needed.

7) External Slot for SD Card---So I installed a SanDisk 128gb Micro SD card which was loaded with my music, pictures, home videos and files. I still have 75 gb left on my SD Card. According to Gsmarena, this device holds a SD card up to 256 GB.

8) Camera---I actually took some inside and outside pictures and saved them to my SD Card. The pictures (indoors and outdoors) are very OK, not professional quality, yet I am happy with the pictures, they are excellent for sending in email or even Facebook. My videos also came out well so I am happy.

9) Battery life and Device Coolness---Battery life I find GOOD, and I am a heavy user of apps. I watch lots of YouTube videos, Facebook, listen to my music etc. My battery starts off at 100 percent, then after one hour of heavy use it shows close to 87 percent. This is because I am a heavy user.
***Device coolness/Battery coolness---I use an app Widget free from Playstore called Battery Solo. Normally, it When I press, the highest it showed me was a cool 88 degrees Fahrenheit. This is excellent and the battery a device stays cool, it never overheats.

10) OTG (On the Go), which means with a USB/Micro adapter, you can insert a USB Flash drive, USB mouse, keyboard (one at a time). I use this to copy files from my Flash drive to my tablet or vice versa).

Only one Con, but not serious...

1) USB Port is MICRO not a type C.  No problem as all my other devices are Micro USB except my 2017 Samsung Tab A 8.0 tablet.

* Would I purchase this device over again? Yes, in a heartbeat because my Samsung Tab 2 813 model has 64GB storage and Nougat OS. It is a wonderful phone at a reasonable cost, so I recommend it. I rate this 5 stars.

Since I am a Techie, if you have any questions about this device, please ask me in the comments section. And I will answer all questions about this device. Thanks you for reading my review, I hope that it has been helpful for you in making your decision about this tablet.

The Samsung Galaxy is supposed to be the top-selling Android product, that  is why I decided  to try this tablet . I have always owned an HTC, with the exception of an iphone and an iPad that I tried, which in my opinion are an inferior product compared to the Android. This particular tablet is supposed to be a high-end Galaxy product, not the latest version but none the less,  higher price tag. This Android device does not come close to the performance of my HTC U11. I know the HTC is a phone, but an Android is an Android. The specs include an 8-core processor, 3 GB of RAM and a 4000mah battery. In my opinion the overall speed of the unit barely compares to my last 4 core and 2 GB of RAM Android. When reading this review keep in mind that I have only added about 10 apps  to this tablet since  I  started using it , in other words ,  not enough downloaded apps to effect the performance at all. The battery most certainly does not live up to what the description boasts. Even as I am writing this review,  I am constantly having to correct the speech to text, which I use most of the time because it is quicker than typing and works excellent on my other Android. I could keep going, but buy now I'm sure you know that I am disappointed with this purchase. Who knows, maybe the S3 works a lot better. I didn't want to put out $500 for a tablet that I just use mainly to control my home theater. I purchase the extended protection plan with the tablet. I had the tablet checked and I was told there was nothing wrong with it, so the lack of performance is not due to a defective product. I am going to buy an HTC Nexus 9 and sell this one used, because it is past the return period. For anyone out there who is buying this tablet, I am selling my tablet along with the extended protection plan. I paid $350 + the price for the extended protection plan. I purchased it new 2 months ago. If anyone is interested, you can find it on eBay. I am not sure yet how much I will be asking for it, but obviously less than what I paid for it new. In all honesty I feel bad selling it to somebody but I was told there was nothing wrong with it and maybe I am just used to the excellent performance from my HTC U11. All though, I will say, that if you use speech to text a lot, you definitely do not want this tablet.

I upgraded to this tablet from a 3rd generation Kindle HD Fire 7". I bought the kindle tablet intending to use it mostly for reading with some video watching and web browsing on the side but it became immediately evident that the Kindle Fire is not a strong enough tablet to handle video streaming in high quality, and the silk browser left a lot to be desired. The only thing I was able to do was read with the built in kindle app and even that was laggy and froze up at times. I owned the tablet for less than a year before they rolled out an update that essentially bricked the tablet. So I spent months researching tablets and decided that I wanted an Android tablet, a software that I was already accustomed to using and would be able to sync easily to my phone and my computer. Originally I wanted the Nvidia shield tablet because it had the best specs and screen resolution, but it was sold out everywhere. The Galaxy Tab S2 8" was second on my list, and I managed to get it for $249 during Black Friday. I can say, I have not been disappointed. It's an amazing little machine. It's basically a bigger version of my Galaxy S7, and at times it runs more smoothly than my phone. I can stream 1080p videos with no stutter or lag. It's a breeze using Chrome to browse the web, and I have dozens of reading apps to choose from in the Play Store, so I can find one that fits my specific needs. The 8" was the perfect size for me. I didn't expect 1" to make much of a difference from my old 7" tablet, but the Tab S2 feels so much bigger. More text fits on one page and the tablet is slim enough that it doesn't hurt my wrist when I'm reading in bed. When people ask what a good reading tablet would be, I always recommend this one. It's so versatile, and I honestly think it's the best in its price range. Despite not having the highest screen resolution of tablets in its class (and something that made me hesitate with purchasing it), I can say I've often found myself marveling at how crisp and vibrant the picture quality is, so it's not at all something you should worry about.

The only minor flaw I can think of is the speaker placement. There's 2 small speakers on the bottom of the tablet, so when the tablet is turned sideways for video viewing, you're only able to hear sound from one side of the tablet and it can be annoying at times. And the sound quality is decent, not amazing, but I still enjoy watching Netflix without needing to find a pair of headphones. Just wish there were additional speakers on the top of the tablet as well.

I bought a case for this tablet that I think really compliments how slim and sleek the design is. It's the ProCase in the color Black. Feels like leather, converts into a stand and comes with a free stylus/ink pen combo. Beautiful case for this beautiful tablet, I highly recommend it.

Before the update, if I was frugal I could go for 5-6 days without charging!  Post update I can't go longer then a few hours.  Plus it discharges 50% overnight while in sleep mode.  It's now a $400 paper weight (it's to thin to be a door stop).  From reading the Samsung forums, it's plain to see this is a problem many users are having (it looks to me like it goes back to at least June of 2017) so that's 10 months now with NO HELP from the Samsung to fix the problem they forced on their users without any way to back-out the update.  If you have one and it's not doing this yet - don't take the latest OS updates from Samsung or you'll likely have a paper weight too.  I'll be happy to update this review once Samsung does the right thing and patches the problem.

I've owned this tablet for over a year now, and I would not buy another Samsung Tablet. For whatever reason, Samsung has blocked US models (via firmware I assume) from accessing WIFI channels 12 & 13 (EU) and 14 (Japan & other countries). This means that if you travel anywhere in the EU where channel 13 is used, business, home, caf, or otherwise, you won't be able to connect and that's just too bad for you.

I've called up Samsung tech support and tried to sort this out, but the techs got confused between TV Channels and WIFI channels. Once I was able to educate them, they forwarded me to a "supervisor" who informed me there's nothing to be done about the Samsung-created limitation. Yes, the US doesn't allow Channels 13 or 14, but that pertains to broadcasting. There's no reason why a client shouldn't be able to access 13. There's no law against that. By way of comparison, my acquaintance's iphone and ipad, sold in the US, can access Channel 12 or 13 in the EU.

So, if you decide to buy this tablet, just know that Samsung has needlessly crippled it for international travelers.

I researched extensively and had even been considering buying a new Surface Pro or Lenovo Mixx 520 (and still might) but also felt the need for a first-rate Android device. It came down to either this or the Huawei Harman-Kardon Mediapad M3 (or possibly waiting for the new M5), but in the end I was persuaded by the simple fact that Samsung products are so prevalent, with so many available aftermarket accessories and, due to this predominance, a stellar level of quality; essentially I think of Samsung as the Toyota of electronics.
Further, I own a Samsung Galaxy S7 Edge and have been thoroughly impressed with the speed, quality, durability and value. Again, abundant aftermarket accessories are available, and having owned the phone for more than a year without a single performance or other failure of any kind, this contributed to my decision.
Having received the tablet and used it for a few days I am convinced I made the right choice. The screen is superb in terms of color saturation and resolution, such that it is an absolute joy to use doing anything, from game playing to reading to web surfing. The speed of the processor is exceptional (be sure to order the newer SM-T713NZKEXAR version with the faster and superior Qualcomm Snapdragon 650-series CPU) and never lags or hangs, and file transfers to the Samsung 128GB MicroSD I purchased with the tablet are performed with excellent speed.
This tablet is incredibly thin, and is actually easier and more comfortable to hold using my also bought Kaka case, and with this, in combination with the equally excellent IQ Shield glass screen protector, I feel that my Tab S2 is entirely protected, and the glass screen is a perfect fit under the case with no adverse impact of any kind.
Due to the lower cost of the black version of the S2 I decided to buy it, rather than the somewhat more attractive grey or white versions, reasoning that with a case, which I believe to be an absolute necessity for protection of the investment, installed, the color difference would be of minimal consequence.
I'd also like to mention that I'd considered buying a 10" tablet, but my experience with my Amazon Fire 7" had convinced me that a smaller tablet is preferable for a variety of reasons; it is much lighter and easier to hold, is the perfect size for Kindle and website reading (using one hand) and easy to carry in a back pocket or in cargo pants leg pocket.
In all, I am extremely pleased with my spiffy new Galaxy Tab S2 and the case and screen protection, and very impressed as always with Amazon in terms of quality, selection, speed of shipping and customer service.

I purchased the Galaxy Tab S2 9.7" from a brick and mortar retailer in late 2015. Maybe it's improved since then, but here's my experience.
When first purchased it was close to $600 and performed very well. I got a bluetooth keyboard and it essentially replaced my laptop. Apps ran smoothly, the features were great - I was very happy with it and treated it very carefully.
About a year after purchase, it starts having some trouble coming out of standby. Pressing the power key or the home key doesn't always turn the screen on, but it's infrequent and solved by just pressing a couple more times. No big deal.
Over the next few months it declines. Soon I'm having to press the power button multiple times to wake it up. Then rebooting it entirely. Then when it does come on, the screen is gray and static (for lack of a better description). It's lit, but displays nothing. A hard reboot fixes this for a while, I delete extra apps that might be causing any problems, factory reset, etc. I talk with Samsung techs, they suggest sending the tablet in for repair but that'll cost a MINIMUM of $200 which by then I am not willing to spend on a tablet I already paid $600 for.
Eventually it refuses to turn on at all. Nothing I do gets it to work again. The best suggestion I've gotten is that it might be a software problem... but it no longer is recognized by my computer when plugged in. So it's a brick.
I'd think it's just my bad luck, but in researching my issue I found plenty of other people who had similar problems with the screens just... randomly no longer working. I'm switching over to a new brand for my next tablet and wondering what I should do with this brick I've got sitting here.

Now the not so good...1) Per the review submission guidelines we are not supposed to describe the shipping experience so I will leave it at - not positive.
2) After receiving the product and setting it up I registered it with Samsung. That was easy enough, but Samsung is stating that the warranty is expired. I am expecting the best, but planning for the worst and hope to not need the warranty, but the description on the Amazon product page and the order confirmation page both state that the product has a valid manufacturer warranty.
3) Now about the product itself...From my reading I got the impression that one could move apps and files from the 32GB of internal storage to a micro-SD card so I purchased a high-end and relatively large SD card to save internal storage space. I followed the tutorials provided by Samsung to move apps to the SD card, however, only one of 20+ apps so far has given me the option to move it to the, at this point, expensive and useless SD card. This has resulted in over half of the internal storage already being allocated and I only set it up two days ago. I am remaining optimistic that once I begin downloading other file types such as images, media files and documents that I'll be able to download them directly to the SD card with out needing to do double work by downloading them and then needing to physically move them from internal storage to the SD card.
4) Finally in regards to RAM...I did some comparisons between different tablet models and manufacturers and I was fairly confident that for the size limitation of wanting a tablet that fits the hand and so needing something in the 8" range, which is very difficult to find in newer models and manufacturers, that I was getting one of the best "under the hood" set-ups for the price point and size constraint. However I'm a little skeptical, because without really running anything on the tablet I'm consistently utilizing over 50% of the 3GB of RAM. It makes me wonder what performance will be like when multi-tasking, or running resource intensive tasks like streaming video? Only time will tell, but from the bit of research I've done the articles say that Android 7.0 is supposed to really positively impact multi-tasking and RAM usage.

It'll sound like I work for Amazon, but I don't. I have had Kindles for years. Love them. When it came time to upgrade from the last one, and thinking I want to also use the next device - instead of a laptop - for email, browsing, etc. I did a lot of research and landed here. Should have continued to research. Main beefs:
(1) Not impressed with the andoid OS. Not even a little. Buggy. Forces you to install apps left and right, when simply using a browser would be fine or even better. Buttons mean different things depending on the app.
(2) Reading what's out there, I was given a clear impression the Microsoft tools like Word and Excel are free on this device - nope - you can view, but you can't edit. When you call to figure it out, Microsoft and Samsung point the finger at each other, and that's when they don't want to charge you for tech support.
(3) this is not a Samsung issue, but while on the subject of Microsoft - Outlook for Android is really poor. It was developed for a 4-5 inch screen, and I am holding a 10" device...
(4) Charge time, using the charger that was provided with the device, is unbelievably long. I think you need to charge an hour to get 45 minutes of completely standard use. Kindle is FAR better.

One problem I ran into is that screen casting doesn't work with Chromecast devices (though the Chromecast option in all the apps I tried DID work). I bought a third party MHL to HDMI adapter with charging capabilities and that works well, but its still not as convenient as being able to mirror the screen to a Chromecast device.

The SideSync app from Samsung was a surprising benefit to this tablet. It allows you to manage notifications and mirror the tablet's screen on a PC complete with mouse and keyboard integration. I am using it to assist with app development and its working great.

If the tablet continues to work well I will be very pleased with this purchase overall.

I bought this in January and I use it every single day for work, school, and personal. After nine months of use, the tablet has shown no reduction in speed or performance. I don't think it has ever crashed or reset in all the time I've had it. I bought the official Samsung keyboard to use with it, which was a bit expensive but works very well. The battery is still excellent. I am in a master's program and I am able to take notes in two back-to-back three-hour classes without every needing to plug in - Impressive! I now get my school textbooks on Kindle whenever possible so there's no need to carry books. With Kindle for texts, Evernote for notes, and MS Word for brushing up papers, and 15GB of free storage always available via Google Docs, the only thing I need to bring with me anywhere is my tablet. It's nice.
This is not a computer replacement for me though. If I'm writing a paper I'm doing it on my PC with a full-sized keyboard. But I use this for taking notes, making YouTube videos, Skype, Netflix viewing, games, taking minutes at meetings, making journal entries, making mind maps in class, and organizing absolutely everything with Todoist.
Oh, and even though it's "only Wifi," I just use my phone as a hotspot when I'm out and about and I'm able to get online anywhere, no problem.

It's the best portable computing device I've ever had and it's a lot cheaper than an iPad.

Great product, BUT Technical Support is HORRIBLE.  I bought one on March 23, 2017, in July it quit working.  I sent it in for repair on Jul 26,2017.  On Aug 7th, 2017 I received an email offering either cash back less 33% depreciation or an exchange unit.  I asked for an exchange unit on Aug 8th, 2017 via email.  I followed up by phone call on Sept 18, 2017 and was told they would ship one as soon as their exchange department received my unit from their repair facility.  I followed up again on Sept 24, 2017 and tried to get a commitment as to when a replacement might be shipped, and got a stern dressing down that the status was "IN PROCESS", and that there was nothing else they can do.  It's now Sept 10, 2017 over one month after I responded that I'd like the offered exchange, and still nothing.  I USED to be a loyal Samsung customer, but they will not be receiving any further of my business ever. I do like my Samsung Galaxy Tab s2. Its features are what you would want with any tablet. However, it has some glitches that are puzzling, even confounding.
First, the good:
It is beautifully thin. I have never seen such a thin tablet. That makes it delightfully light to handle. I almost didn't want to put a cover on it. However, if you order one of the Fintie covers this does not add that much weight or bulk of it but still protects well. The tablet upgraded immediately to Android 7, Nougat and so it has the latest OS (although it will be antiquated by the time I post this). The tablet is not overloaded with bloatware that takes up a lot of the 32 gb space and so that is a plus. The 9.7 display is just right for reading and viewing. The display is sharp in definition and is very colorful and responsive to videos being played. The display has 4:3 aspect ratio so you can read digital publications in portrait orientation without it looking squashed. That aspect ratio may not fill the screen with photos that are taken in the landscape orientation and you will have black bars on top and bottom even in the landscape orientation.
The Bad:
The touch screen works well enough in most cases and responds to the touch adequately for web sites, applications and publications. However, inexplicably with some web pages and some electronic publications the touch screen is unresponsive. For example, every time I go to Google news and I want to open up a news item to read I have had to tap the article link up to 6 to 8 times before it responds and goes to that news report. Sometimes my taping causes the screen to jump sideways to an adjacent web news category instead of opening the news report. Additionally, if I am using my finger to scroll up or down there is a great tendency for the screen to jump sideways instead of scrolling up or down. If I try to deliberately scroll up/down by going slowly the screen will start wiggling sideways as if it is desperately trying to jump sideways to adjacent web pages. The screen will also do this with certain publication reading apps. I never had such a sideways sensitivity with a tablet. This certainly did not happen with my previous Galaxy Note 10.1 2014 loaded with Android 5.1 OS. I do not know if this is a glitch with Android 7 or with this tablet. Also, the battery life stinks. If I charge it overnight and use it on and off the whole day the battery will wind down to 15% between 6 to 8 PM.
Still, for the reasons given in the good paragraph I am happy enough with this tablet and I hope it will serve me well for a couple of years before I have to replace it.

Firstly, use a large paper clip and firmly press in the tiny hole until it clicks. The slot may have released BUT it's almost impossible to grasp it to open. This was one of my best buys ever.  I've had it now for about 18 months and am still totally impressed with the Tab S2.  Here are the things that impress me the most:

1. Super high-resolution screen. Though I own the 8" model I can see everything crisp and clear with vivid colors. The resolution here is the highest you will find for any tablet and it's worth it.

2. Quick processor speed. This tablet is very fast in accessing apps, e-mail, calling up photos, music, etc. It's more like a computer than the typical tablet.

3. Super slim design. This is about the thinnest tablet you will ever own. It's weight is negligible and it passes the "back-pocket test." By that I mean that it fits in a man's pants back pocket. Though an 8" screen the outside dimensions are about what you commonly find for 7" tablets.

4. Upgradeable Android. One shortcoming of many tablets is that they eventually become obsolete. You cannot upgrade Android and eventually the apps you have will not run on your old version of Android. I haven't needed to upgrade yet (I'm running Marshmellow) but like to know that I can.

5. Superb integrated keyboard and leather case. No the keyboard/case is NOT included and NOT made by Samsung but by Fintie. For under $30 you can have a great leather case and keyboard (the case can be used and fits perfectly even if you do not tote the keyboard around with you). I am a touch typist and can use this keyboard for fast typing. Though small it's like a real keyboard with keys that depress and was made just for the S2.

What don't I like:

1. The cost. This is a very pricey tablet relative to others that are out there. Yet I think the investment is well worth it because this is NOT a typical tablet but much better.

First major problem occurred less than in a year. Orientation stopped working. We had to drive 40 miles to the nearest support. They just wiped out all our data and reset to firmware. After that, Android updates stopped working giving "Update failed" all the time and giving the suggestion to use "Smart Switch". I googled the issue and realized that this is a quite common problem. Installed Smart Switch on my Mac and tried to make an update. Update stopped in the middle with a failure notice and a suggestion to use the "Emergency recovery"!!! Don't need to say that Emergency Recovery failed as well, as well as "Device Initialization". Updating USB drivers in "Smart Switch" menu resulted in other error messages. Now the device is a useless brick.
In conclusion, you can use this tablet, if you don't care about security updates, and that somebody can steal your personal information, hack your email, bank account and so on. Don't try to use any of so called "software" from Samsung to fix the issue. It was my third and the last bad experience with Samsung devices.

Update. I managed to make device working by flashing firmware by Linux open-source program Heimdall using the firmware from the third party web site. Still, don't think it is normal that to make an update you need such expertise or go to the service center in 100 miles.

1.  Screen- the 8 inch super amoled is beautiful and bright.  I have no issue with viewing this indoors at 20% to 30% brightness even though most other tablets require at least 50% to be near as good (my Ipad Air 2).  As anyone who follows tech knows, Samsung makes the best screens in the business.

2.  Speed/Performance- This tablet has a mid-range Snapdragon 652 octacore SOC and 3gb of ram.  I was not expecting this type of speed from this tablet.  It opens apps almost immediately and multitasking and switching between apps has been a breeze.

3.  Speakers- This tablet comes with 2 bottom or side firing speakers that I was expecting much from but they are loud without distortion but they don't really provide much base.  Still, when in the shower playing music I have not issues hearing the songs.

4.  Upgraded to Android 7.0 as soon as I turned it on.

5.  Standby time is much improved in this android tablet or android version.  Not sure which is the reason.  I had a Samsung Galaxy Tab Pro 8.4 and the standby time was horrible on android version 4.4.4.  I could charge it and leave it unplugged overnight and the tablet would lose 20% of its charge.  This tablet however has only lost 1 to 3 percent overnight.

6.  Samsung's game mode- Samsung, once you take the android 7 upgrade, provides their game mode features which allows both performance boost for 60 FPS a second gaming and high quality resolution or you can choose other performance to help the game or conserve battery.  There also an option to lock the recent and back buttons on the tablet to keep you from accidentally hitting them while deeply immersed in a game.  I love this feature as I use to go nuts on my Galaxy Tab Pro 8.4 from accidentally hitting buttons while deep in a game.

There are many more Pros to this device that I don't want to go into, it's android so it is very flexible.

Cons

1.  4:3 aspect ratio when watching movies.  When viewing netflix and others you lose so much screen real estate unless you maximize the video which blows it up and then you lose detail.  This tablet is great for games, web browsing, reading and productivity but movies are a little bit of a miss.

2.  32GB internal storage- Even though this tablet allows for expandable storage, keep in mind that Samsung's flavor of android as far as I can tell does not allow for adoptable storage (ability to turn you SD card into system internal storage by formatting it as such).  I installed all my games and social apps but had issues where I ran out of storage.  I went in and moved apps that allows for storage on the SD card which helps some but 32gb is still too small.  I bought the newest 32gb Samsung Pro SD card (https://www.amazon.com/dp/B06XWZ7L1Q/ref=cm_cr_ryp_prd_ttl_sol_28) and have only been able to move roughly 6GBs of internal storage to it.  Also, this is a tablet coming straight from the manufacturer with no telecom carrier stipulations so why tie the buyers hands with putting apps on the tablet that cannot be uninstalled.  For instance, what if I don't use Microsoft Office or many of the Google Apps that come preinstalled?  Yes, they can be disabled but they cannot be uninstalled which takes up valuable limited storage space.  I looked for but could not find the mythical 64gb variant out in the wild.  If you want to tie the buyers hands why locked apps then please provide a 64GB or 128GB version of this tablet, at minimum.

3.  Battery life: Standby time is exceptional as listed above but in usage this tablet really drops from 100 percent to the mid 80s rather quickly.  I may get 5 to 6 hours of screen on time but that's highly doubtful.  I am going to do further testing.  I might be spoiled by the Ipad and the fact of the larger battery capacity of the larger tablet.

I can't do anything with it but throw it in the garbage.  Don't buy this product.  I am a Samsung  fan but I think that I will invest in an Apple product the next time. I bought this tablet to replace my old 2013 Nexus 7 and to have an Android-based system to accompany my iPad Air 2. It has excellent resolution and display color.  Good WiFi performance  60Mbps on home 2.4GHz channel. It streams movies from my home network very well. Performance is very good with games and Office 365 apps  Word, Excel, etc. I expanded the memory with a 128GB uSD card and have ready access to cloud-based storage, e.g. Dropbox, OneDrive, and Google Drive. I loaded it up with apps, pictures, a few movies, and a ton of Kindle ebooks, Audible audiobooks, and music.  I was able to readily connect and use multiple Bluetooth devices: Microsoft foldable keyboard, Microsoft mouse, and Bose earbuds.

Sample workflow using this tablet in lieu of my laptop: While traveling, I can import RAW images from my Canon DSLRs SD card into the tablets uSD card using an OTG card reader and ES File Explorer. I create the same file structure on the uSD card that I would use in my home system. I can review and edit/convert the RAW images with Photo Mate R3 or Adobe Lightroom. Im particularly happy with how fast RAW images are rendered and viewable on the tablet. I can share the generated JPEGs by (as one example) copying them to a USB flash drive connected to the tablet with an OTG cable.  At home, I can transfer the whole lot to my PC network using WiFi, USB cable, or by removing the uSD card and using a USB 3.0 card reader (fastest). This workflow works very nicely for me and is almost as efficient as if I were using my laptop.

I purchased an IPad 2 ($710) at the end of March in 2011 and it still works today, although the battery doesn't last as long as it used to, and I get "A problem has occurred on this web page" on a lot of web pages that I look at. I have looked at the current IPad's that are offered today and am not really impressed with any of those. After a lot of research over several weeks, and Amazon offering of $399 instead of 499, I bought the Galaxy Tab S2. I purchased an Elemsy 9H screen protector, and a MoKo protective cover for the tablet to ensure that the bumps and occasional drops wouldn't destroy the tablet. The tablet has quite a few features that I didn't expect to see in the settings. Device Maintenance is a feature that allows you to clean up the cache and all of the other junk that's clogging your tablet up and you can also choose if you want to Optimize the tablet for longer battery life. I have found that the longest battery life on the ultimate power saving mode is 64 hours at 100% charge, but I find that I am charging the battery almost everyday. The Sound Quality and Effects can be customized using the included Equalizer that you can adjust manually or choose various settings such as "Rock" or "Pop".
And playing Lady Gaga's "Born this way" video on YouTube sounds excellent. You can even choose the "Concert Hall" effect feature in the settings under "Sound". The display is not as sharp as I would like but I have changed the default picture to an abstract from the ZEdge app and all is now looking pretty darn good. BTW, as soon as you connect this tablet to WiFi, it updates to Android version 7.0 Nougat. From reading about the new OS, there are more enhancements going on in the background than the foreground of what you can see. I do like the "Quick App Switching" feature as well as the "Split Screen" feature. Hopefully it will last 3 or 4 years before I buy another one.

I felt obligated to write this review as I had a difficult time trying to find a decent, small Android tablet since the Google Nexus 7 2nd version. Let's face it, from a user experience (UX) perspective, most Android tablets in the market, without sugar coating it, are just plain bad in comparison to iPad's. Scrolling is jittery, which basically makes everything else redundant. The Nexus 7 2 was in my opinion a very good Android tablet at an excellent price point. The Samsung Galaxy Tab S 8 was also fairly good but mine (which I had for 2 years) started to lag after about a year or so of use, despite not having very many apps. I believe the "bloatware" was the main problem (which seemed to get worse after the system upgrade to Marshmallow), so I was dead set against purchasing another Samsung tablet.

I'd seen the Samsung Galaxy tab S2 8" last year and baulked at the price, having not been completely satisfied with my current Samsung Tab S as already mentioned. But last week I smashed said tablet in frustration when it started lagging again, so needed to buy a replacement tablet. Again, Samsung was off the list, but when I did my research, there just weren't any 7" - 8" tablets in the market that I couldn't guarantee I wouldn't throw against the wall again. So while walking through an electronics store, I saw the Tab S2 8, at a very reasonable price point, as the Tab S3 being launched soon. A quick flip through some of the apps and a look at some web pages, I was surprised at just how smooth everything was. It's the closest Android tablet to an iPad that I've used and looks exactly like an iPad Mini.

The bloatware seems to have been reduced. I purchased a version with Android 6.0 (Marshmallow) out of the box and 7.0 (Nougat) was delivered a few days ago. I'm extremely pleased with this tablet. It's very light and comfortable to hold, and was surprised to find that it fit in my back pocket. Apps load quickly and the user experience is extremely smooth. The screen resolution is superb.

My only negative comment would be that the speakers are positioned at the bottom of the tablet (not on either side as with the original Tab S8) and the sound quality is not the best. It's certainly not bad, just not on a par with the previous version. And the output from the speakers is quite low, but youll probably be using headphones so this shouldn't be a problem.

There hasn't been any issues with the speed of the tablet since the upgrade to Nougat, in fact it seems smoother. Id highly recommend this device to anyone looking for a small Android tablet. I believe its currently the best device out there from a price / quality perspective.  4 out of 5.

Easy to set-up, the UI is not half-bad, though a memory hog, at nearly 8GB...(and you can replace with other launchers, I use Nova Launcher from the Playstore), bright colours on browsing, a good size for single-hand operation (a bit tight, but do-able), and very lightweight. However, I'm thinking of returning mine because I can't stand the yellow-tinted screen. It seems crisp and clear in store, when watching a 2 minute trailer or demo video, but when you have it in hand and watch an hour long programme, the blacks are not quite rich enough, the colours are either too yellow/blue/off and there's a constant green/yellow tint to people's skins that I can't get rid of. There is no way to change the colour on the screen via the device itself (except for 3 presets that don't help at all), so I downloaded an app from the Playstore to change the screen colour, but it's still not good enough. The green/yellow tint prevails.

I've Googled the issue and apparently it's a common Samsung screen problem, apparently due to the AMOLED screen used by Samsung. It's not a swatch of massive green across the screen (that is an LCD issue), but rather that everything looks...too yellow or green. It's just annoying. Comparing that with my Nexus 5X phone (Google) or Moto X screen, and Fire HD 10, there's a world of difference in true-colour display. And seeing that I bought this primarily for media and entertainment consumption, I can't keep staring at a screen I can't stand.

Unfortunately, at this price range, the options are limited. I tried the Samsung Tab A as well and that had such obvious pixelation that it also went back. I bought the Fire HD 8 from here, and the screen was even MORE yellow, so went back. I'm not a fan of iOS, either. So where does one go from here, unless willing to accept subpar electronics? The search continues...

Tons of reviews on this guy already on so I'll just add my very BIG quirk about this otherwise perfect tablet:

The finger print reader is frustrating at best.

I've had this tablet for a little close to 1 year now and I've been going through securing all of my electronics with finger print long where applicable.  I'm a security consultant and I can tell you this is a MUST for all devices that has access to your email and browsing history.  My main point is this: It doesn't matter if you implement strong unique passwords for all your accounts if you leave just one device that can be used to reset all your passwords!

For my phone I have an iPhone and my wife has an iPad with Touch ID and they work at about 99.7% of the time.  With my S2 this is more like 50%.  Even when I dedicate recording all five fingers with just my right thumb (seriously Samsung, why limit it to just 5 fingers??) and I give it a full 360 degree run around, with quite possibly every range of touch I could apply it for it STILL fails me, locks me out having to wait 30 seconds or have to type the whole password... no thank you.

In recent weeks Samsung announced the "face" un-lockable S8 which it's in so many ways very cool and easy to use but now we're finding that S8's can be unlocked with a picture... this tells me how much QA Samsung puts into their stuff as well as how little they care about security implementations.  By all means a very speedy tablet that can do tons of things that my wife's iPad can't, but I won't risk my security for this guy.

I recommend looking elsewhere for an Android tablet.  We purchased our unit in October 2016.  We keep the unit on the charger 100% of the time and use the tablet to watch Netflix in the kitchen.  Twice now our tablet has refused to boot up.  After checking on-line we see a great deal of posts with other people having the same problem with Samsung tablets.

The battery is fully charged.  We know our charger is working since I can test that it does indeed charge when I plug it into my phone.  We have tried many on-line recommendations of holding the power button on for 1 minute, to holding both the power and volume key, to.. sigh..... seriously... why don't you make us all perform a rain dance at the same time??

In December when this problem first appeared it took a couple of days of repeating the many listed steps you can find on-line before the unit would magically boot up.  Here we are in March 2017 and the unit has decided to not boot up again.  I am taking it back to the store.  I STRONGLY RECOMMEND DO NOT BUY, there are other options out there that actually work reliably!!!

I am baffled why this Samsung product even has this problem in the year 2016/17, but for the price it is unacceptable that the tablet for some odd random reason decides it is going to be difficult to turn-on.

When I contacted Samsung, I was told that they do not provide warranty for tablets sold in Amazon.  Then I contacted BLINQ to claim the problem I was having and they just washed their hands saying their warranty was only for 30 days.  Finally I decided to take my tablet to a Samsung Service Center a, when they opened the tablet they found that the problem was the charging port flex board, it was NOT a Samsung part.  I contacted again BLINQ claiming that they refurbished a tablet with cheap and non-original parts, they just said that they receive too many tablets per day and they do not have control on the repairs that are done.  I told them they should take ownership of this problem but they keep saying that they only cover the first 30 days.

So watch out if you buy a refurbished tablet form BLINQ, you may be getting a cheap repair on your tablet with no warranty but the fist 30 days. I ended up paying $185 for the original part, in the end way more than if I have purchased a brand new tablet with 1 year warranty form Samsung.

My previous review was shortly after I got the tablet. I would love to give this 5 stars as I initially did, but to be honest, this thing is junk!!
When I got it, it seemed to drain the battery pretty quick and take awhile to charge. I read somewhere to reset it to Factory Default. Sure enough... it seemed to fix the issue. No biggy. No negative marks for that. I bought this at the very end of January, 2017. On April 12th, is when the troubles began. When I went to bed, the battery was at 50%. I got up the next morning, and it was completely dead. Keep in mind that I have all Power Saving options turned on. I took it to work with me to see why it would do that (I've been in IT for 33 years). But first I had to charge it. I had it charging for 3 hours, and it was only at 10%, and there was a red X on the battery. I let it charge for a total of 17 hours, and it only made it to 56%. Anyway, I contacted Samsung, and sent it in for repair. I got it back last night (April 27th). It was back at Factory Default. It was at 68% a 9pm last night. This morning it was at 28%. I had nothing installed at all. No files or music copied. I took it to work with me this morning. I had it plugged in from 7am to noon. It went from 26% to 56% in 5 hours.

I contacted Samsung. Spoke to a rep. Gave her my previous case#. I told her that I wanted a replacement. She said that she needed to transfer me to another dept. So 45 minutes on hold. Next thing I know, I had been disconnected. Luckily, she called me back on my cell phone. She wanted me to troubleshoot. I refused as I did troubleshooting on my last case, and that this is the exact same problem... so she got me in touch with a "tech". He wanted me to send it back in!!!! I said "So that you can keep it another 2-3 weeks and send it back still broken". He said YES. Let alone, I couldn't hardly understand him. I told him to send me a new one. NOPE!!! He said that they do extensive testing on these before sending them back. I told him that their test sucks because it came back in the same condition as when I sent it to them. He refused to send me another one even though this is a lemon. I told him to send me whatever he needed to and I hung up on him.

I then called T-Mobile (where I bought it as I need Broadband). They are replacing it!!!

I got a new tablet the other day... and I love it!!! I got so sick of Apple's proprietary crap. And that anything you want to add to the iPad, you had to use iTunes or buy a 3rd party software. And the iPad has no flexibility. You buy a 32gb iPad... you are stuck with a 32gb iPad. Cannot increase the storage capacity at all.

So... with an Apple, if I want to copy music over to the iPad, I have to make sure it is in the MP3 format otherwise, you can't even copy it over via iTunes. OK... not a big deal as most music files are this already. But what about video's?? Oh... let me tell you about that!! With an iPad, it has to be MP4 x264. Not all videos are this format. You have quite a few video formats (AVI, WMV, MP4, MKV). To watch a video on the iPad, you have to convert the file over to the MP4 format. Now... here's the real pain in the ass part of an iPad. Pictures!!! With music and video, you can just drag and drop the files over via iTunes. Pictures?? NOT EVEN. Here's what you have to do... create a folder, and copy the pictures you want on the iPad to the new folder. Then go into iTunes, and you have to Sync that particular folder.

I got a new Galaxy Tab S2. It's 32gb... however, I can add an SD card to increase the storage. I happened to have a 64gb SD card lying around at work... I threw that in there. So now I have 96gb of storage. And the neat thing... I can copy my music or videos over, no matter what format they are in. I installed VLC media player from the Google store.... which was free, and this is what I use on my computers as well. VLC plays anything!!!  Pictures??? Just drag and drop!!! Easy!!! Oh... and now the really cool part. I bought a $5 dongle that plugs into the power port... and it allows me to attach my thumb drive to the tablet. Take the 96gb that I already have on the tablet... add in 128gb thumb drive... lots of space. I can put a bigger SD card in if I want. Oh... and with my thumb drive attached, I can watch movies directly from that instead of having to copy the file over to the tablet. How simple!!!

The Samsung Galaxy S2 is my first tablet and I like it. You can read all about its virtues elsewhere. I got it mainly to capture notes I make on the go. I absolutely hate having to transcribe my handwritten notes later into a computer. The handwriting analyzer is very good at accomplishing that task. However, there are some serious shortcomings I wasn't aware of as a first-time tablet buyer.

1. You can only have one application open at a time!  Yes, they advertise split screen, multi-apps, but it's mostly not true. It only applies to certain "selected" apps, like email and google maps, not the apps I am interested in, such as Acrobat and Google Docs or Kindle Reader and Word.  This restriction makes it virtually impossible to read a document and write notes about it.  I might not have bought if I'd known that.

2. Tons of bloatware come pre-loaded on the device and cannot be removed. This essentially means Samsung offers about 30% less available memory than you think you're getting.  Maybe it's their way of forcing you to buy supplemental SD memory. Be aware.

3. Wifi-only tablets don't work in cars -- only where there's Wifi.  That's not a problem at home, but anywhere else, you are at the mercy of whatever Wifi is available -- slow and clunky at school and public places, unsafe in hotels, privacy-robbing in stores, unstable and unsafe in airports, none at all on the road.  If you get a 3G tablet you have a cellular microwave connection everywhere, but of course you then have to pay a monthly fee to a carrier like Verizon.

Conclusion: Despite many attractive features, a tablet is not anywhere close to being a substitute for a full-sized computer. I thought tablet  technology was more advanced than it actually is. A tablet is mainly for consumption of information (e.g.,movies, pictures, games, and shopping), but not for production of content, which typically involves synthesis of information from several sources.  Since you can only have one app open at a time, you can't even look up a reference while you're writing. I need to  make marginal notations even to  read a novel (and if you've ever tried to do that on Kindle reader, you know it's not practical). So this "one app at a time" restriction is a potentially dealbreaking constraint.

The T713 tablet is fantastic.  The display is bright, sharp and fast.  Making it an ideal choice for drone pilots (my requirement).  However be aware the tablet doesn't play well with the most widely used drone apps  DJI GO and DJI GO4.  When the USB cable is connected between the tablet and DJI remote control while everything is powered on,  the display starts flashing messages so fast you cant read them, basically locking up the tablet until your either reboot or unplug the cable.  Another issue i discovered about the T713 was it wouldn't connect to my AT&T Sierra Wireless hot spot, which I've owned for years and never once had a connection issue from hundreds of various devices.  As it turned out my hot spot was configured to allow both WPA and WPA2 wifi connections, for whatever reason the T713 didn't like that and i had to reconfigure my hot spot for only one of the two encryption methods.
In summary T713 appeared to be exactly what i wanted in a tablet but came up long in BUGS.  None of these problems existed on the earlier model T710, so I'm hoping they will be resolved in the near future or I'll just wait on the S3 due out Q3.

Battery life is also porr.

These aren't disasters, but the point of a tablet is convenience and this is supposed to be a premium product.  Except for the screen, it's what I'd expect from a discount model.

Update:  also the GPS stopped working after the OS upgrade, Samsung tech support was useless (claimed it doesn't have GPS in the first place).

I have owned a Galaxy Tab S 8.4 for about two years.  It is such a great small format tablet, I find I have left my laptop in my closet at home and haven't used it in months.  I made the investment to buy the Bluetooth keyboard for it and while small, it's a great add-on.  I can even print from it to my home printer and the screen and processors are awesome.  I was heartbroken when I thought it was dead.  It wasn't charging.  It kept rebooting.  I mournfully ordered the S2 8.0 hoping it could replace by S.  The S2 is a great small tablet.  Plenty of power.  Screen is amazing.  It's a great small tab.

However, I just couldn't get past the change in the screen.  The widescreen format of the S 8.4 allows for streaming full screen.  The S2, with its 16:9 screen, shows streaming content with letterboxing.  It makes the viewing area noticeably smaller.  With today's world of Netflix, Amazon and other streaming trends, viewing area is important.

The rest of the specs are spot on.  It's fast and the screen is beautiful ... I just didn't like the 16:9 format.

Unfortunately, it doesn't look like Samsung is going to make another tablet with the same screen shape specs as the S 8.4.  I know some folks don't like it, but I do.

I'm happy to report I was able to fix my S 8.4.  Seems my Samsung OEM charger was bad, causing the tablet to struggle charging.  New charger, and a factory reset on the tablet, and we're good as new.  The S2 is a great tablet.  If that's your choice, it's not a bad one.  However, the older model, the S, is one I find to be superior to it's next-gen replacement.

OK, so $249 isn't technically "Affordable" to some people, but it's  heck of a lot better than the Samsung Tab A 8.0 which was a disaster.

This Tablet is more like the Samsung Galaxy S6 of tablets. Last year's model, but very nice and everything works. While you still have to manually purge some of the RAM and storage space sometimes like with the Tab A, and there's only about 4000 mAh on the battery, this device does well to conserve memory, space, and energy.

You're not going to find a nicer tablet for less unless another on-brand competitor (LG) makes it.

Personally,  I don't like off brand tablets, and after my recent review with a budget tablet, I think it's sade to say you won't find anything better than this device at a lower price point.

There's no cellular network access on this device, but that's fine with me. I can use the mobile hotspot feature on my phone to connect to the Internet that way.

Getting a micro SD card is always recommend even though there is 32GB of internal storage. 3GB of RAM is also modest.

Consider this if you need an Android tablet that does everything from reading books on Amazon Kindle to playing Minecraft. Although, if you spend all day doing the latter, consider getting an Anker power pack or the Samsung power pack.

Also not included but highly recommend is the Samsung Galaxy Tab S2 8.0 Book Cover and one of those retractable pens with the soft rubber stylus on them.

Update #2 .. Back to 5 stars as Samsung took care of it easily and quickly .. Customer assistance was responsive, shipped both ways on Samsung's dime .. came back repaired and no sign of any problems 4 months later ... of course no problem is the best, but if the company stands behind the product and repairs it then I am satisfied.

Update:  Unfortunately I have to downgrade from 5 to 1 star .... perhaps temporarily as I am hopeful my issue will be resolved.

At about the 6th month mark the screen started acting up as 1 half of the screen would periodically malfunction and show a alternating pattern of light and dark grey lines or simply show half of the previous page.  At first infrequent and resolved by restart,  the problem progressed until a point where the device could no longer be used.  The device was very gently used.  To me a device of this price, from a respected manufacturer,  failing like this in so short a time is unacceptable.  Now the hopeful part.  Today, my first opportunity to contact Samsung support, went pretty smoothly as the device was verified as still under 1 year warranty and the tech advised me that as long as the device is not 'liquid or physically' damaged that they would repair it free of charge.  As the device looks like it just came out of the box and has never been near water I am hopeful this will work out.  Unlike many manufacturers, Samsung (to their credit)  provided free UPS to mail the device to their repair facility.  I was quoted 9-11 days turnaround.  Of course I wish that this had not occurred, but so far Samsung seems reasonable about their responsibility to the customer and as we all know 'stuff happens'.  At the end of this repair effort I will update again and if I have a working device I will return the review to 5 stars as I think post purchase support is very important and often lacking.

I also make a point to close apps when I'm going to be done with them for the next few hours, rather than leave them running in the background. I read a lot on my tablet, view a few movies or TV shows, email and text via Chrome, and usually find I need to recharge about every day to day-and-a-half.  Charging seems to take about 4 hours.

The tablet is very much like a large version of my Galaxy J7 phone.  I really like my phone, so the tablet was a breeze to use, right off the bat.

If you tend to use a lot of battery-eating apps, you'd probably be unhappy with this tablet, but otherwise, I'd highly recommend it.

I took a chance on this tablet since it seemed like the best Android option out there. Initially when I first got it I was impressed with the looks and build of it. It's very thin and the display is sharp. After using it for 5 months a few things have really bothered me enough to give this only 2 stars.

First, the WiFi loses connection repeatedly. It will lose connection, come back for 5 seconds, lose it again and reconnect. It does this ALL THE TIME. I thought maybe it was an issue with my router but none of my other 5 devices in house exhibit any issues at all.

Second, the battery life is horrendous. Seriously this thing is lucky to get about 5-6 hours of good use before it reaches 10% battery. This is coming from a full charge too.

Third, the Samsung bloat. Way too many useless apps that you can't remove without rooting or the debloating tool. Why Samsung insists on doing this is beyond me. Very annoying.

If you're in the market for an Android tablet, my recommendation is to look elsewhere. Unfortunately, there aren't many options out there in the Android space which is sad because really there should be.

Then a message pops up stating 'An unauthorized factory reset has been attempted' which definitely wasn't something I expected. Then it asked for a Google username (email address) and password, so I attempted to log in with mine, only for it to pop me back out to the prior screen with the same message.
This is when I called Samsung Support to see if the tablet had been registered for warranty purposes. So far it had not been registered with Samsung, but was told to do a factory reset to 'as new' condition it would have to be sent to Samsung. Oh yeah... send it in and wait a few weeks before I could give my S.O. her gift? Nothing doing!
So I returned it immediately.
NOTE: Credit where credit is due...
1. Although this issue was beyond the control of Samsung as the manufacturer, Samsung Support was VERY patient, understanding and as helpful as possible under the circumstances.
2. By return shipping the item the same day as I received it, based on my Amazon correspondence it appears the credit may be processed before the original charge hits my credit card account. (Hopefully!)
HOWEVER... this does NOT absolve Amazon for the item not be 'New' as advertised condition, which is why I did NOT ask for a replacement item and will never buy any electronic device from Amazon again.
No, I wouldn't have decided that after only one issue, but two other electronics I purchased in the last 6 months were defective upon receipt so I figured 'three strikes and 'you're outta here!'

This tablet is the best I've owned to date which really doesn't say much since I've only owned one other tablet in my life which was a Asus Transformer running a Tegra 4. Obviously, this tablet is superior to that and even the iPad Air 2 in many ways.

I am a medical student and was seeking a necessary tablet to use as a combination study tool I can take anywhere. I must say that this tablet has the functionality for studying medicine which is currently unmatched by Apple unless you spend a million dollars for upgrades or the iPad pro. I was between semesters and on a limited budget so I chose Samsung and here's why:

Cost for memory - Like I stated earlier the Tab S2 is superior to the iPad Air 2 in many ways, one being memory. At the same price point, you get literally double the memory (32GB vs 16) which is a major deal for me because I require tons of files, pdfs, and videos that use a bunch of space. Yes you can use cloud services like One Drive and Apples Cloud but they both are slow, touchy and not the most reliable. Either way, you get cloud services for both. Samsung comes with 100GB of space for One drive and more over, if you are a student, chances are you get some type of cloud service through your school for free anyway. I spent $16 for a Samsung Evo+ 64 GB micro SD card that brings my total space to about 96 GB. For Apple conversely, to just get a 64GB version of the iPad, you have to spend $100 extra dollars for the base model. Even still, the iPad is not expandable.

Screen. The screen is brighter and more colorful than the iPad Air two although they both have the same resolution. However, this is the only area that the iPad has an edge over this Tab S2 which is that the iPad screen has built in Palm rejection similar to the surfaces. This means you can use a stylus on the screen without your Palm interfering with the input. This may seem like a possible deal breaker but Android OS has a counter to that; fact that iOS's most popular note taking app, Notability, isn't all that great. Plus Notability costs money and if you want to sync Notability notes between your iPad and Mac, you will have to pay for two separate licenses. Inkredible is available on Android exclusively and is completely awesome. It disables the part of the screen your palm touches which can also be customized. Perfect for my needs and combined with Samsung's split screen multitasking feature, can take notes from the lecture slides (use Xodo) while Jamming to music on Tidal (which is also superior to apple music) Best part is, Tidal Premium is 5 bucks a month if you are a student. Apple is also beginning to be shady with their billing. For instance, if you were to download Spotify, Netflix, or Tidal through the apple store, they will attach a monthly "Apple Store Surcharge" making your 9.99/mo Netflix cost 12.99/mo or whatever they decide to charge in addition.

RAM: 3 GB is perfect for loading large files and moving them around. The iPad only has 2GB and I have seen people get a little annoyed when loading thier ipads while loading big files especially moments like class getting ready to start.
Processor: Fast. No lag period.
My colleagues often have Apple buyers remorse once they see how much better work flow is on this compared to their iPad. If you are in between the two, this one is better unless money is no object for you and want to get a iPad pro.

Other thoughts: I recently obtained an Air 2 free through my school and I must say the Samsung screen is obviously superior to the Air 2. The blacks on the Tab look like it does when the device is powered off: Completely black. The blacks on the Air 2 glow with a maroonish tone. And actually the colors have a reddish hue to them on the iPad. And no it's not night mode. When I activate that, the screen turns SUPER red. Which i think the ipads "reading mode" may be easier on the eyes than the samsung but maybe its just visual preference. The screen is also not nearly as bright or colorful. With that being said, the cameras on the iPad are nicer on both the front and rear facing cameras and the speakers are louder than the Tab S2. I use a blue tooth portable speaker when I want to jam so this doesn't bother me. The iPad also is extremely heavy compared to the Samsung. The heavyness makes the Air feel more solidly built but I know the screen isn't as durable as the Samsung's gorilla glass. However, although the Tab S2 comes with a 2 AMP charger, it doesn't offer fast charging like it's cell phone counter parts. The Air actually has a 2.1 Amp charger but seems to charge at the same speed as the Samsung. I have an 813 version so it comes with a Snapdragon 652. It feels a lot faster than the A8X which I found leggy in comparison coming out of the box.

Others have complained about the "bloatware" Samsung loads on these tablets, but honestly I don't agree with that at all, seems like just the right mix of apps for me, with tons of space still available. I especially like that I have the option of directly accessing files on my external flash drives without having to upload them somewhere first (although you do have to buy a USB adapter for that). All in all, I feel this tablet does everything iPad does as well or better, costs much less, and so far no sign of sign of any glitches. If you're thinking about making the switch, or if you've never had a tablet and would like to try one, I don't think you'll be disappointed.

Just wanted to leave a comment. If you research the Galaxy S2 you will find that there is a big difference between the old 2015, 710/810 version and 2016, 713/813 versions. The processors are completely different. In fact, I've read benchmarks that put the newer 713 tablet at about 25% faster than the 710 based on that major difference. (Although it is possible that some of the OS changes from 5.1 to 6.0 may optimize the speed more too). Also, I think the new processor draws less power increasing battery life a bit (but I'm not totally certain on that.)
I saw people comment that they were getting the old model instead because of price. I thought people should know that paying a little less for the old 710 could be a bad idea because the 713 is much better.

This is by far the best tablet I have ever owned. It is fast, powerful, thin, and even lighter than my phone. I, typically, dislike using extreme exaggeration but I just had to let all of you Amazonians know that this is without a doubt the best tablet that I have ever owned and I've owned quite a few (i.e., iPad mini, iPad 2, iPad 4, Galaxy Tab 10.5, just to name a few). I went back and forth on whether or not to get the iPad mini 4 or this and I am soooo glad that I decided to go with the Tab S2 (don't get me wrong, the iPad mini 4 is a great device but the iOS ecosystem is just a bit too restricted and dependent on iTunes for my taste). No, the battery life is not as good as the iPad mini 4, but it, honestly, is pretty good and it charges much faster than any of the other Galaxy Tabs I have, previously, had. The Tab S2 is so thin and light that you forget that you are holding it sometimes. I primarily use it to catch up on the news (reddit, flipboard and espn), eBooks, and audio books and the processor handles everything that I throw at it. And yes, this is the model that came with Marshmallow pre-installed. Other than my cell phone, this is, definitely, my go to device. All of this said, if you are on the fence and trying to decide between this and an iPad mini, then get the iPad mini 4 if you are an iOS ecosystem person or get the Tab S2 if you are an Android ecosystem person. BUUUUT other than the battery, which I've stated is not an issue for me, the Tab S2 is the better all-around tablet, in my opinion.

I didn't buy this through amazon -- it was a gift. I use amazon A LOT, so I wanted to add my thoughts on this device.

Samsung Galaxy Tab S2 (SM-T713) 8.0 inch Review:

This is truly a fantastic tablet and I am very satisfied with it!
I am coming from a Google Nexus 7 2013 tablet, so this tablet has really been a breath of fresh air. The Nexus 7 was showing its age a bit with how slow it was getting (especially with YouTube) and also how unresponsive it was becoming in regards to recognizing touch inputs in the middle of the screen. Shame! I really loved that device.
The Tab S2, however, has been a terrific upgrade. It has taken some getting used to, but it has been worth it and I definitively recommend it for anyone looking for a smaller (8 inch or smaller) tablet.
Pros:
- Its quick and very responsive. I primarily use this device to browse the internet, do some light research, use YouTube, Reddit, and do some light shopping. So, I am not running the latest graphically intense android games on this device and most apps I use are not as processor-intensive as others available, but for what I use this tablet for it has been responsive and very quick. Everything works really well and in terms of its processor, there is nothing I believe is lacking.
- 3gb RAM. This is a lovely addition and allows more background apps and more chrome windows! Haha, the RAM pairs up nicely with the processors and adds to the general responsiveness of device
- THE SCREEN! Oh my goodness. The Super AMOLED screen is gorgeous with rich and deep colors that make every image pop. Watching YouTube videos have never looked better and images, gifs, and memes on Reddit look great. It took a bit for me to get used to the 4:3 aspect ratio (coming from the Nexus 7s 6:9), but honestly it works great and makes reading articles, stories, posts, and internet pages a lot easier.
- The battery is great. I don't have problems with how long it last. I can usually get by with 2-3 days of light use with it, with 2-3 hours each day. I charges quick as well (compared to the Nexus 7), so thats really nice.
- Micro SD card expansion slot. This is really, REALLY nice. I know a lot of devices have this now, but Google is stuck in the Middle Ages and haven't really made the jump to allow this feature, so having a tablet have this is awesome. I put in a 64gb EVO+ in there and it works great and adds a whole lotta storage to the device.
- The wireless range is MUCH better than my old Nexus 7. Im not sure if this is the standard now, but boy oh boy, its nice to be able to still get a good connection to our router from the furthest reaching spots in our house.
- Its super thin and super light. Both things are great and both add to the general futuristicness (word) of the device.
- The build quality is top notch.
Cons:
- Bloatware. This is the BIGGEST con for me. I understood that there would be bloatware when buying this Samsung device, so I guess I knew what I was getting into. Its not terrible and horribly intrusive, but its there, it updates itself (the Samsung app store and all the pre-installed apps that come with it), and every so often it gets in the way. But honestly, after putting in a 64gb SD card in the device, installing an icon pack and a new launcher, the look and feel of the device can be tailored to your liking, and thus the bloatware is sort of hidden. Ill wait a year to root the device, so I can uninstall the bloats ma bloats.
- The protruding camera on the back.  Now I don't use tablets to take pictures, never have and probably never really will. So the camera on the back protrudes a fair bit out of the back, and really just becomes this protruding (to use that word again) thing that I don't really use. Sort of mares the Tab S2s super thinness.
- The speakers suck. Like really, really suck. Theyre poorly placed on the bottom of the Tab S2 and watching videos in a horizontal fashion really leaves a lot to be desired. I was spoiled by my Nexus 7s speakers  they weren't THAT much better, but the very fact that there were two speakers placed either side of the device meant sound was distributed much better.
Well thats my two cents on this device. Overall its really a phenomenal device that is held back by a few shortcomings (hence the 4 stars). In many ways it is a HUGE step up from my Nexus 7. Samsung makes quality products and I might just be sticking with them for future tablet purchases. That screen. Hmmmm that screen. Its gorgeous.

The overall response is great.  I ordered the tablet, the micro SD card, and case at the same time, and they all arrived in the same box.  Right now, my only gripe is the micro SD card.  It installed easily, but everything I have downloaded has gone directly to the internal storage.  I wish there was a way to choose where each download went.  I can't believe it would be that hard for the cpu to access the card.  Another con:  I once got a less expensive tablet, and within days after the warranty expired, the charging port stopped working, fell apart, beyond what my local tech could repair. Debated between this and iPad for months... and... finally just made the leap - and am glad I did.

The iPad is fine also, especially if you have other Apple devices - which synch very nicely via iCloud / iTunes.

But, I learned you can do much the same between the Tab S2 and your Android, Windows and Apple Devices via Google Drive, or Skydrive, or iDrive, or maybe even iCloud / iTunes.

And... you can use apps like Telegram, or Google Hangouts to have free text messaging between those same devices (similar to iMessage).

Most of the critical apps you use on your idevices, are also available on your Android devices (or very similar ones).

And... I bought a Roku Streaming Stick to cast / stream my Tab S2 screen (apps, music, videos, etc.) to my Vizio Smart HDTV.  So, I can download and use my ATT Uverse Mobile app to watch most of my favorite cable TV channels on my Vizio HDTV at my parent's house when I'm away from home.  So I never miss Fox News Channel Live, or Fox Business Channel Live, or Halmark Channel Live, or whatever on the Uverse channel list.  It works superbly allowing me to use my Tab S2 as my tuner right from my recliner.

The screen is superb - a bit better than the iPad's screen.  And it operates just as smoothly and as fast.  And, has much more storage, expecially with the optional micro memory card.

I was a bit unhappy with the volume from the speakers, but that was resolved by downloading and installing the OS updates, and the Volume + app.

And there's more... it comes with Microsoft Office - so, you can create and edit your Office docs right on your Tab S2... if... it's really necessary (easier with larger screen / keyboard of your notebook PC).

The rest is in all of the comparative reviews available online - which echo much of what I've noted here.

While Apple has some great products... the competition has pretty much caught up and surpassed them in some respects.

So... there you have it - you won't be disappointed.
