I have been an iPhone and iPad user since the first iPhone and full-size iPad came out.  Over the years, however, I have come to enjoy Android side of the world more.  I have one primary reason for liking Android better, and that is the ability for my photo backup apps (or any app) to run in the background without having to open the app.  iOS limits background activity from occurring non-stop, even though some iOS apps have found a way around this limitation by basing the background activity on your GPS location changing.  With Android, apps can upload all the time.

A couple of years ago, I switched my primary cellphone to Android, so I am quite familiar with Android. I always had an iPad as my primary tablet, because I never felt like the Android tablet offerings were good enough to match my iPad.

So, about this tablet:

Keep in mind I am a long-time iPad user.

Over the past month, this has been my go-to tablet.  I let my iPad Air sit on the shelf for the entire month.

This tablet does everything my iPad Air does. With the exception of my movies that were purchased in iTunes, I have been quite at home on this tablet.

It is sleek, lightweight, and looks great too.  It is very, very slippery though.  I have almost dropped it a few times.  The front is all glass, framed by metal sides.  The back is a plasticy feeling material, and is the cause of the slippery-ness.

The headphone jack is on the bottom, which is a minor annoyance.  For a tablet designed to usually be held in the portrait position, having the headphone jack on the bottom is an issue when you are lounging on the sofa, with the tablet resting on your chest.

Another minor annoyance, is that the volume of the internal speaker doesnt get very loud, even turned all the way up.

According to my Geekbench testing, this tablet scored a single-core score of 1454 and a multi-core score of 4879.  For comparison, my 2014 iPad Air scored a single-core score of 1478 and a multi-core score of 2683.  Again, my iPad Air came out in 2014, while this tablet is the newest revision  (as of this writing in July 2016) of the Samsung Galaxy Tab S2.

So, heres the deal.  I am really picking at little things like the speaker volume and placement of the headphone jack.  This tablet is excellent and very iPad-like in terms of quality, performance, and build.  As someone who has been sitting on the fence about going all-Android and leaving my iOS devices behind, this tablet has pretty much sealed the deal.

Note: The above review is for the white 8 inch Galaxy Tab S2, which I received for review instead of the 9.7 inch Galaxy Tab S2.

We have a few tablets bouncing around our home at the moment.  These devices are primarily used to stream TV shows, check Facebook, and play games.  I personally use my phone, a Droid Turbo with 5.1 Android OS, for most of my activities.  These activities include those mentioned above, but I also use it for recording interviews, shooting video, and taking photographs.  I've never really used a tablet (I have a laptop) other than to help my kids out.

The Samsung Galaxy Tab S2 might just change my mind about that, though, as I have fallen in love with this device.  It runs on the 6.0 Marshmallow Android OS, has a slim design, and includes both password and fingerprint protection (although you don't have to use the fingerprint if you don't want to).  The high resolution screen (up to 2048 x 1536 pixels) pops with color and makes webpages and social media sites look a lot nicer than they really are.  There are also some excellent tools available with this tablet like PowerPoint and Excel.

Photo quality is good, but I have seen better and actually prefer my Droid Turbo for photos than I do this tablet.  It does play video quite well, though, and I often use it to watch shows instead of watching on my small phone screen if I'm not at home to use my television.  The only other drawback is the speaker location, due to the fact that I often cover the speaker with my hands while using the tablet.  Other than these minor (and I mean really minor, hence four stars and not three), this tablet is great.

I find myself using it at higher frequencies with each passing day, and I'm more and more impressed by it with each use.

***My review is the for 8 inch model***.  I requested the 9.7 inch as part of the Amazon Vine review program, but was sent the wrong one.  I already have a 9.7 inch iPad so I actually like the 8 inch for travel etc.  The Galaxy Tab S2 is my first Android device.  I have been using this tablet for web browsing, youtube, and basic email.  For those functions the Galaxy tab has worked well.  Setting up the device was easy and I was up an running in just a few minutes.

Things I like

1. Size- I actually like the 8 inch size for travel and easy of carrying around.  If I didn't already have a 9.7 inch tablet, I would prefer the larger size, but since I already do have one this size is nice.

2. Ease of setup- the Android setup was easy and only took a minute or two and I was ready to go.

3. Google Store- so far the Google app store is easy to use and my regular apps that I have used on my iPad are there.

4. Camera- the camera on the Galaxy seems very good for the price point.  The zoom is clear and easy to use.

5. Expandable storage- mine is a 32gb model so not sure if I will need more but it is a nice feature to be able to add a storage card.

6.  Price- good price for a nice tablet.

Things I don't care for

1.  Edges- the edges of the table are not rounded and I find it not as comfortable as other tablets I have used.  The 8 inch model may contribute to this as there is no sizable border, requiring me to put my thumb on the size of the tablet.  Not the most comfortable when using for longer period.

2. Screen- while the screen is very sharp and clear, I have noticed how white background turns a blue color when not viewed straight on.  Don't get me wrong, the screen is very nice but when holding the tablet at an angle, white background color fades to a blue color.

3.  Multitask and back buttons- Samsung has next to the "home" button, a button for seeing multiple apps (to close) and a back button.  While very easy to use, Samsung decided to make the buttons light up and the lights turn on and off a lot.  I haven't found a way to disable that feature, so it can be distracting.

4. Touch screen- maybe its just the Android version, or its the screen, but sometimes when closing out apps through the multitask it takes several times for the app to close when touching the "X" close button.

5. Speakers- they are a bit weak but for everyday use they get the job done.

Overall, I like the Galaxy Tab S2 and it is a worthy tablet for the price.  There are just some things that could be more refined to make it a great experience.  But, for the price it is expected that you are not going to get perfection.

EDIT:  After watching more videos in different lighting, I have noticed a persistent issue with the screen in dark settings.  For example, the dramatically lit scenes in The Walking Dead or Game of Thrones.  Rather than a consistent luminance across the screen, there are bands of brighter spots and darker spots.  The light bands seem to show where the screen is edge lit.  It's not terrible, but it makes certain types of shows difficult to see, since the already low contrast is exaggerated.  I have modified the score accordingly.

How do you choose the best tablet or phone, when there are so many similar models from different brands?  I struggle with that every time I choose a new one.  But, having used all sorts at this point, I have come to like this tablet more than most, and it is nearly perfect for reading or watching videos.

BUILD

There is nothing interesting about the S2 design.  The front features the generic Samsung button and the back is a bland matte surface.  They are tacitly admitting that people are going to put a case on it anyway, so why bother?  Still, it feels solid and pleasantly lightweight, making it better for reading than I expected.  The screen can't beat an e-reader, but sometimes I need color and size.

The only ports are SD, which is under a flap, and micro SD.  I am disappointed that this 2016 tablet doesn't have a USB C port, but that probably isn't a deal breaker for most.  Having an SD card more than makes up for it.

DISPLAY

One of the biggest differentiators between low and high end tablets is display quality.  The S2 doesn't disappoint in that area, with a 2048x1536 AMOLED panel that gives sharp text and detailed imagery.  That aspect ratio is more suited to PDFs and magazines than movies, so expect black bars with video.  The contrast is good for this price range, but certainly not the best I've seen.  Likewise, there is a bit of motion smearing that I wouldn't accept in a high cost tablet.

CPU

The speed of this tablet was surprising to me.  My main experience with Android has been low end devices, while my experience with iOS has been the newer devices.  This tablet was faster and smoother than both.  It's great to use a tablet that I don't have to worry about weighing down.

BATTERY

The battery life has been excellent so far, even with demanding tasks that tend to kill battery life.  As long as I charge it once a day, I usually have the bulk of the battery remaining.  It also charges quickly.  I will update the review if the battery doesn't hold up well over the next couple years.

FINGERPRINT READER

Early fingerprint readers on phones were such a nuisance to use that they never gained much traction, but they seem to be popping up in a lot of devices now.  As with the new iOS devices, the reader is fast and almost always reliable.  While it makes unlocking the tablet easier than using a password, also keep in mind that fingerprints don't share the same legal protections as passwords and are relatively easy to "hack."  Still, it's a nice feature when done right, and it is done right on the S2.

CAMERA

Cameras on every tablet I've used have been mediocre, and the S2 front and rear cameras were no exception.  I have included a macro and distance shot with this review.  In short, they work for video chat or a quick snap, but lack the clarity or contrast you would expect in a good phone camera.

SPEAKERS

Speaker quality on the better tablets tends to be the worst for some reason.  I guess placing them where they face the listener is seen as diminishing the style and it is just assumed that you will be using headphones or external speakers.  I recommend doing that, because the speakers are not loud, front facing, or good quality.  They do the job in a quiet area, but just barely.

SOFTWARE

Is Samsung software a detriment to the pure Android experience?  Probably, but it is not a big problem.  If you download the Google Now launcher, you can pretend that you are using stock Android and rarely will your fantasy be broken.  But, the included Samsung software such as the camera app is just not as polished or modern as the frequently-updated Google apps.  While Samsung apps can't be deleted, they can be ignored and replaced with others.  A mild annoyance for me was trying to figure out Miracast video streaming, since Samsung renamed it and moved it out of the display settings.  But, I eventually got it working.  Expect to run into minor frustrations like that if you are used to stock Android.

A benefit of the S2 is that it is so popular that you can also find tutorials on loading more stripped down Android versions if you prefer.  If you just want the tablet to play movies, read books, and run apps, then you don't need to change anything.

SUMMARY

The Galaxy Tab S2's display, performance, and battery life make it a premium tablet at a good price.  If you don't mind working around some Samsung quirks and the soulless industrial design, I recommend it.

I helped my aunt select the older 810 variant as a replacement for her dropped tablet less then a month ago.  As a result I also helped set it up, for all apps, accounts, etc,. and got to know it fairly well.

When Samsung released the 813 version, and had it available for a sale price, it was an impulse buy I could not resist.

I have not used the two side by side, but based on memory the 813 feels a little snappier, and somehow the screen seems somewhat more matte vs what I remember from the very glossy 810.

This tablet is phenomenal for browsing, reading, video, and and generally any task that I have thrown at it so far.  It is the first of my 5 tablets, on which I can use "desktop mode" and really do not have any kind of low performance that I normally end up experiencing on other tablets.  (Tip, install Firefox, and add the Adblock plus plugin.)

I also ran 3DMark, and other benchmark tests.  Overall this tablet is excellent, and even does OK, in gaming, though not great, due to high resolution.  Do not order this tablet to play games, get the Nvidia Shield K1 instead.  It was able to provide a far smoother experience specifically with games, and did nearly 3 times better in benchmarks.

So why the 3 star off rating?  Three reasons;
-Wifi adapter could be better.  My shield tablet, Note 5 and laptops are able to send and receive data at a higher rate.  This tablet tops out at about 50mbps.  My speed fluctuates somewhat, but is usually 70-90mbps down, 35 up.

-Speakers.  Why is Samsung always behind on speakers?  Due to being tiny, and on the bottom edge of the tablet, the results are disappointing.

-Inability to remove "Guest" mode from lock screen.  It's actually a great feature to have available, to be able to say, turn on, hand the tablet to a friend, and they can use it without peeking at your private stuff.  The problem is the option is ALWAYS on from the lock screen, and even if a pin is added to the "Guest" account, the guest account can still be deleted from the lock screen!  This means that even without ANY technical knowledge, or ability, just about anyone can pickup the tablet, anytime, and make use of it immediately.

My main gripe is with the speakers, and the software.  The wifi adapter is definitely enough for just about any kind of use, so that is more of technical nitpick on my part, that my older cheaper hardware does better.

Overall though, this is the BEST tablet to get as of June 2016.  Out of the box it is completely trouble free, exquisitely made, and easily the equal of the much higher priced ipads.

For the past 3 years I've been using a Kindle Fire 7" tablet, which I thought was cute at the time, but this is so much better I should have gotten one a long time ago.  I spent a whole lot of time and research on one particular issue so I thought I would take the time to share this information in case it might help someone else.  One of my requirements for a tablet was to be able to connect to my TV in some way to play the contents of the tablet onto the TV...you can't seem to find a tablet these days with an HDMI port (my Kindle Fire had one, but when I connected it to my TV the video would just freeze and I had to re-boot the tablet to recover).  Anyway, I thought I could use the USB/HDMI adapter made by Samsung (MHL adapter), but wasn't sure if it would work on this Galaxy S2.  I called Samsung and they told me it would work....they make 2 different ones, they told me to get the 2.0 version and it would work.  WRONG.  After a whole lot of time and research, I finally found some information that confirms this tablet does NOT support MHL, so you can't connect to your TV using that method.  I also have a Galaxy S5 phone which the adapter does work on beautifully, and a Galaxy S7 phone which it does not work on.  So I returned the adapter.  This S2 Tab has 2 alternative methods which you can use to connect it to your TV, however you must either have a "smart" TV or do what I did, and purchase the Fire TV stick, and then connect through that.  Select the "mirroring" option on your Fire TV stick, then on the Galaxy Tab turn on the "Smart View" option.  You can find that on one of the settings buttons on the pull-down buttons on the top of the screen where the Wifi, Bluetooth, and Auto Rotate options are located.  Once you make the connection you can view anything that is on your Galaxy Tab on your TV.  There is a second option to accomplish this called "Quick Connect", however that is limited as to which particular content you can share from your Tablet to your TV.  For example of you want to play a video from the Internet and then see it on the TV screen, the Quick Connect feature will not allow you to do that, so you have to use the Smart View option instead.  I hope this information is helpful to prevent someone else from going thru all of the effort I went thru to determine if I could use the MHL adapter with this device or not, which is extremely difficult to determine until you actually try it yourself.  If you research it, you will find conflicting information, where in some places it says that MHL will work on this Tab, and other places where they say it will NOT work on this Tab.  As I mentioned, Samsung customer support (on the phone), gave me the wrong answer to this question.

All my previous tablets were eReaders, the latest being the Samsung Galaxy Tab 4 Nook (10.1 screen), so this machine was a bit of a departure for me. Most of my comments will be in regards to how my experience with the Tab S2 compares to the Tab 4.

To start with the Tab S2 is noticeably lighter than the Tab 4. The S2 is 13.83 ounces to the Tab 4s 17.38 ounces. (Dont believe the number above. The S2 is NOT .3 ounces.)

The Tab S2 feels more responsive than the Tab 4, which it should since the S2 has twice the processors running at a faster speed. I don't feel like Im waiting for anything aside from whatever lag comes from my current internet connection.

The Tab S2 is smaller in both directions, but loses little in the way of screen real estate. The S2s screen is wider but shorter than the Tab 4, but I don't notice a real difference in display area, primarily because the S2 has twice the resolution of my previous machine2048 x 1546 versus 1280 x 800. Of any feature, the screen is where the Galaxy Tab S2 really shines. It is amazingly crisp and clear. It takes the work out of readingeven when my eyes are tired. Cant say enough about the AMOLED display. Wow.

The OS in the S2 is Android Lollipop and it was a bit of an adjustment from the KitKat Im used to. Nothing insurmountable. I was able to be productive right away, but there are some subtle differences. So far, I like Lollipop better. It seems a little easier to find what Im looking for.

Battery life appears to be about the same with both machines, with the S2 maybe being a little better.  (Doubtless because it is a brand new battery.)

One of the nicest features of the S2 is in the setup. After answering a few initial questions, it located my Tab 4 (which I happened to have in the same room) and asked me if I wanted to upgrade / port from that. When I answered yes it proceeded to find all the apps I had on my prior machine and started downloading them. It also gave me the option to bring over all my files, as well. Very handy feature and will save most users a lot of time.

Overall, the Samsung Galaxy Tab S2 is a great machine, and a worthy upgrade if youve had your previous tablet for a year or so. The price tag feels a little pricey to me, but Im sure it compares favorably with other tablets with similar specs. The screen, speed and expandability are top notch, and worth paying a little extra for.

OS UPDATE (7 May 2017)  TAB S2 UPDATING TO ANDROID 7.0 Nougat

This review is for those contemplating upgrading from the old T710 or T810 to the new T713 or T813 versions.

I am comparing the old Tab S2 (SM-T810) to the new Tab S2 (SM-T813). I have both the old an new versions with me, both with 64GB of internal storage, and I am comparing them side by side.  This comparison is also applicable for the T710 and T713 versions, and for the 32GB versions,

PHYSICAL DIFFERENCES
External appearance -- no difference between the old T810 and the new T-813 in physical dimensions, weight, appearance, or function.

Internal processor - old T810 runs on Exynos chip set, while the new T813 runs on Snapdragon chip set.

OS - old T810 runs on Android 5.1.1 Lollipop, while the new T813 runs on Android 6.01.

Everything else on the spec sheets looks to be identical.

PERFORMANCE
The old T810 puts out an Antutu score of 65,273, while the new T813 puts out an Antutu scor of 81,232
That is one huge gain in performance of the new over the old -- a 25% increase.

Is that performance gain worth trading in the old for the new? -- maybe, depending on the price differential -- I figure its worth a minimum of $100 price differential. If you can get the new version for that or less, then you have a bargain you should probably jump on -- assuming you have someone worthy of passing the old machine on to (my wife in my case), or you can sell it for close to what you paid for it, less reasonable usage and any wear and tear you inflicted on it.

In my opinion, the performance increase is the real, and only legitimate reason to upgrade. And that is really only important for those who engage in 3D gaming.  If you just play board games, there is really little reason to upgrade.  Office apps are generally no going to noticeably run faster -- because they already run faster than you can discern.

USER INTERFACE
There is some visual differences from the native schemes between Lollipop and Marshmallow, which show up in Samsung's TouchWiz Interface. However, I run Nova Launcher on both machines, so for me there is very little visual difference between Lollipop and Marshmallow..

SETTINGS
The settings are almost all the same in old or new version.  However, the location of the settings has been slightly revised  but not so much as you won't be able to find them close by.

USER MANUAL
The T-813 has a different User Manual than the T810.  I put the two manuals side by side and did a page by page comparison.  For the most part they both have the same information, just rearranged slightly different.

NATIVE APPS
Music Player.  The new T813 does not have a native music player.  Not to worry, just go to the Galaxy App store and down load one, or go to the Play Store and download your favorite music player.

Compass.  Neither the old or new Tab S2s have a compass app, but they both have a magnometer.  So download your favorite compass app.

Screensaver / Daydream.  The T810 called it Daydream, the T813 calls it Screensaver  exact same function under SETTINGS >> DISPLAY

Fingerprint sensor.  The fingerprint sensor is much improved  more sensitive and faster on the new T813, over the T810.

VIDEO
To test the video question of whether the new T813 played video slower or faster than the old T810, I ran several 4k videos simultaneously, side by side.  The 4k videos were taken by my cell phone, and the files were approximately 10Mbytes for a 1 minute video  so quite a lot of front-end processing would be required.  In just about every case the new T813 would start up faster, for about a 2-seond lead.  But once started, they both ran at the same frame rate per second.  So, it appears to me, according to my tests, the new T813 starts video faster in the real world.

BATTERY
To test whether the battery on the T813 drained faster than on the T810, I set the screen brightness to 100% on both machines, set the screen timeout to max (10 minutes), loaded the same video in both machines, and then charged both batteries to 100%.  Every 10 minutes I noted the Battery level.  At first I had both sound levels at 100%, but I noticed the T810 at full volume was louder than the T813, so to keep that factor from muddying the results, I turned both sound volumes to zero.  So the results after hours of continuous video playing is:

- - - - - - - - - AFTER 1 HOUR - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - AFTER 5 HOURS
T810 -- 86% charge remaining (14% depletion) - - - - - - - 16% charge remaining (84% depletion)
T813 -- 89% charge remaining (11% depletion) - - - - - - - 32% charge remaining (68% depletion)

So, it does look like the T813 has significantly better battery management than the T810  at least for this test.

So far, that is all I have found. And for me, it was worth the upgrade based on bragging rights and personal preference (but not necessarily based on logic).

If I find more differences that are noteworthy, I will add it to this review.
